title: [GUEST POST] The International Refugee Assistance Project
summary:
Key ideas
- The effectiveness of preparing for something that might never happen cannot always be judged by what is visible on a regular day.
- Extra reserve capacity during a crisis can be the difference between disruption and disaster.
- Partnering with other organizations can lead to the strongest campaign to achieve goals.

Key learnings
- The ground-level work done by organizations such as the International Refugee Assistance Project (IRAP) can make an enormous difference in the lives of individual immigrants.
- Individual cases worked on by IRAP cannot effectively be challenged in court but their work maintaining records simplifies the creation of lists of immigrants affected by new policies.
- Partnering with other organizations can lead to the strongest campaign to force policy changes.

Key questions
- How can the effectiveness of work done by organizations preparing for a crisis be evaluated?
- What other ground-level work is being done that is not glamorous but can make a significant difference in people's lives?
- Which small charities are doing ground-level work and where else can people donate to support the cause?
